page.title: 10THE FISHERY
page.content: During 1985 a possibly unique site was destroyed by gravel extraction. The Fishery lay on the northern bank of the river Kennet and was probably built when work took place on the Kennet Navigation in the 1720's. It consisted of two buildings surrounded by a rectangular ditch which enclosed about 1 acre. The southern ditch formed part of another larger ditch which enclosed about three acres including the 1 acre site. This was not a medieval moated site, but was part of a network of withy beds. The smaller of the buildings was probably a boiler house which was needed in the production of withies for commercial purposes. The larger building was where the site worker lived. In the 1850's he described himself as a fisherman. Until the 1939-45 war there were eel-traps in the ditches.
